section.title: (Optional) Making Infinite Limits a Little More Formal

introduction.p: For those of you who made it through the formal \epsilon-\delta definition of limits we give the formal definition of limits at infinity:

statement.p: Let f be a function defined on the whole real line. We say that

blockquote.p: the limit as x approaches \infty of f(x) is L
f(x) converges to L as x goes to \infty

statement.p:
and write
\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) &= L
if and only if for every \epsilon \gt 0 there exists M \in \mathbb{R} so that |f(x)-L| \lt \epsilon whenever x \gt M.

Similarly we write
\lim_{x \to -\infty} f(x) &= K
if and only if for every \epsilon \gt 0 there exists N \in \mathbb{R} so that |f(x)-K| \lt \epsilon whenever x \lt N.

introduction.p: Note that we can loosen the above requirement that f be defined on the whole real line all we actually require is that it is defined all x larger than some value. It would be sufficient to require there is some x_0 \in \mathbb{R} so that f is defined for all x \gt x_0.
For completeness let's prove Theorem using this form definition. The layout of the proof will be very similar to our proof of Theorem.

proof.p:
There are four limits to prove in total and we do each in turn. Let c \in \mathbb{R}.
Let \epsilon \gt 0 and set f(x)=c. Choose M=0, then for any x satisfying x \gt M (or indeed any real number x at all) we have |f(x)-c| = 0 \lt \epsilon. Hence \ds \lim_{x \to \infty} c = c as required.
The proof that \ds \lim_{x \to -\infty} c = c is nearly identical. Again, let \epsilon \gt 0 and set f(x)=c. Choose N=0, then for any x satisfying x \lt N we have |f(x)-c| = 0 \lt \epsilon. Hence \ds \lim_{x \to -\infty} c = c as required.
Let \epsilon \gt 0 and set f(x)=x. Choose M = \frac{1}{\epsilon}. Then when x \gt M we have
0 \lt M & \lt x & \text{divide through by $xM$ to get}
0 \lt \frac{1}{x} & \lt \frac{1}{M} = \epsilon
Since x \gt 0, \frac{1}{x} = |\frac{1}{x}| = |\frac{1}{x} - 0| \lt \epsilon as required.
Again, the proof in the limit to -\infty is similar but we have to be careful of signs. Let \epsilon \gt 0 and set f(x)=x. Choose N = -\frac{1}{\epsilon}. Then when x \lt N we have
0 \gt N & \gt x &\text{ divide through by $xN$ to get}
0 \gt \frac{1}{x} & \gt \frac{1}{N} = -\epsilon
Notice that by assumption both x,N \lt 0, so xN \gt 0. Now since x \lt 0, \frac{1}{x} = -|\frac{1}{x}| = |\frac{1}{x} - 0| \lt \epsilon as required.
This completes the proof.
